The Related Discourses

14. Learners and Non-Learners

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

At that time, the Bhagavān addressed the monks, “I will explain the learner and non-learner. Listen closely and well consider it. What is a learner? It means a learner’s achievement of right view and a learner’s achievement of right intention, right speech, right action, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration. This is called a learner. What is a non-learner? It means a non-learner’s achievement of right view and a non-learner’s achievement of right intention, right speech, right action, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration. This is called a non-learner.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. A Pali parallel is SN 45.13 Sekkha, but it only mentions the learner in relation to the eightfold path.
Translator: Charles Patton
